column5: HyperStack can use default credentials to connect to IPC$ shares on remote machines.[5]
Stuxnet infected WinCC machines via a hardcoded database server password.[6]
The WhisperGate third stage can use the AdvancedRun.exe tool to execute commands in the context of the Windows TrustedInstaller group.[7]
APT29 has used valid accounts, including administrator accounts, to help facilitate lateral movement on compromised networks.[3][4][5]
APT3 leverages valid accounts after gaining credentials for use within the victim domain.[6]
Chimera has used compromised domain accounts to gain access to the target environment.[7]
Cobalt Strike can use known credentials to run commands and spawn processes as a domain user account.[8][9][10]
Indrik Spider has collected credentials from infected systems, including domain accounts.[11]
Naikon has used administrator credentials for lateral movement in compromised networks.[12]
Operation Wocao has used domain credentials, including domain admin, for lateral movement and privilege escalation.[13]
Ryuk can use stolen domain admin accounts to move laterally within a victim domain.[14]
Sandworm Team has used stolen credentials to access administrative accounts within the domain.[15]
If Shamoon cannot access shares using current privileges, it attempts access using hard coded, domain-specific credentials gathered earlier in the intrusion.[16][17]
Stuxnet attempts to access network resources with a domain accountâ€™s credentials.[18]
TA505 has used stolen domain admin accounts to compromise additional hosts.[19]
Threat Group-1314 actors used compromised domain credentials for the victim's endpoint management platform, Altiris, to move laterally.[20]
Wizard Spider has used administrative accounts, including Domain Admin, to move laterally within a victim network.[21]
APT29 has used compromised local accounts to access victims' networks.[1]
APT32 has used legitimate local admin account credentials.[2]
Cobalt Strike can use known credentials to run commands and spawn processes as a local user account.[3][4]
Emotet can brute force a local admin password, then use it to facilitate lateral movement.[5]
FIN10 has moved laterally using the Local Administrator account.[6]
HAFNIUM has used the NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM account to create files on Exchange servers.[7]
Kimsuky has used a tool called GREASE to add a Windows admin account in order to allow them continued access via RDP.[8]
NotPetya can use valid credentials with PsExec or wmic to spread itself to remote systems.[9][10]
Operation Wocao has used local account credentials found during the intrusion for lateral movement and privilege escalation.[11]
PROMETHIUM has created admin accounts on a compromised host.[12]
Tropic Trooper has used known administrator account credentials to execute the backdoor directly.[13]
Turla has abused local accounts that have the same password across the victimâ€™s network.[14]
Umbreon creates valid local users to provide access to the system.[15]
APT28 has used compromised Office 365 service accounts with Global Administrator privileges to collect email from user inboxes.[4]
APT29 has used a compromised O365 administrator account to create a new Service Principal.[5]
APT33 has used compromised Office 365 accounts in tandem with Ruler in an attempt to gain control of endpoints.[6]
Ke3chang has used compromised credentials to sign into victimsâ€?Microsoft 365 accounts.[7]
Peirates can use stolen service account tokens to perform its operations.[8]
ROADTools leverages valid cloud credentials to perform enumeration operations using the internal Azure AD Graph API.[9]
APT18 actors leverage legitimate credentials to log into external remote services.[3]

APT28 has used legitimate credentials to gain initial access, maintain access, and exfiltrate data from a victim network. The group has specifically used credentials stolen through a spearphishing email to login to the DCCC network. The group has also leveraged default manufacturer's passwords to gain initial access to corporate networks via IoT devices such as a VOIP phone, printer, and video decoder.[4][5][6][7]
APT29 used different compromised credentials for remote access and to move laterally.[8][9][10]
APT33 has used valid accounts for initial access and privilege escalation.[11][12]
APT39 has used stolen credentials to compromise Outlook Web Access (OWA).[13]
APT41 used compromised credentials to log on to other systems.[14][15]
Axiom has used previously compromised administrative accounts to escalate privileges.[16]
Carbanak actors used legitimate credentials of banking employees to perform operations that sent them millions of dollars.[17]
Chimera has used a valid account to maintain persistence via scheduled task.[18]
Dragonfly has compromised user credentials and used valid accounts for operations.[19][20][21]
Dtrack used hard-coded credentials to gain access to a network share.[22]

Adversaries can instruct Duqu to spread laterally by copying itself to shares it has enumerated and for which it has obtained legitimate credentials (via keylogging or other means). The remote host is then infected by using the compromised credentials to schedule a task on remote machines that executes the malware.[23]
FIN10 has used stolen credentials to connect remotely to victim networks using VPNs protected with only a single factor.[24]
FIN4 has used legitimate credentials to hijack email communications.[25][26]
FIN5 has used legitimate VPN, RDP, Citrix, or VNC credentials to maintain access to a victim environment.[27][28][29]
To move laterally on a victim network, FIN6 has used credentials stolen from various systems on which it gathered usernames and password hashes.[30][31][32]
FIN7 has harvested valid administrative credentials for lateral movement.[33]
FIN8 has used valid accounts for persistence and lateral movement.[34]
Fox Kitten has used valid credentials with various services during lateral movement.[35]
GALLIUM leveraged valid accounts to maintain access to a victim network.[36]
Industroyer can use supplied user credentials to execute processes and stop services.[37]
Ke3chang has used credential dumpers or stealers to obtain legitimate credentials, which they used to gain access to victim accounts.[38]
Kinsing has used valid SSH credentials to access remote hosts.[39]
Lazarus Group has used administrator credentials to gain access to restricted network segments.[40]
Leviathan has obtained valid accounts to gain initial access.[41][42]
Linux Rabbit acquires valid SSH accounts through brute force. [43]
menuPass has used valid accounts including shared between Managed Service Providers and clients to move between the two environments.[44][45][46][47]
Night Dragon has used compromised VPN accounts to gain access to victim systems.[48]
OilRig has used compromised credentials to access other systems on a victim network.[49][50][15]
Operation Wocao has used valid VPN credentials to gain initial access.[51]
PittyTiger attempts to obtain legitimate credentials during operations.[52]
Sandworm Team have used previously acquired legitimate credentials prior to attacks.[53]
Some SeaDuke samples have a module to extract email from Microsoft Exchange servers using compromised credentials.[54]
Silence has used compromised credentials to log on to other systems and escalate privileges.[55]
Silent Librarian has used compromised credentials to obtain unauthorized access to online accounts.[56]
Suckfly used legitimate account credentials that they dumped to navigate the internal victim network as though they were the legitimate account owner.[57]
TEMP.Veles has used compromised VPN accounts.[58]
Threat Group-3390 actors obtain legitimate credentials using a variety of methods and use them to further lateral movement on victim networks.[59]
Wizard Spider has used valid credentials for privileged accounts with the goal of accessing domain controllers.[60]

Agent.btz drops itself onto removable media devices and creates an autorun.inf file with an instruction to run that file. When the device is inserted into another system, it opens autorun.inf and loads the malware.[1]
APT28 uses a tool to infect connected USB devices and transmit itself to air-gapped computers when the infected USB device is inserted.[2]
Part of APT28's operation involved using CHOPSTICK modules to copy itself to air-gapped machines and using files written to USB sticks to transfer data and command traffic.[3][2][4]
Conficker variants used the Windows AUTORUN feature to spread through USB propagation.[5][6]
Crimson can spread across systems by infecting removable media.[7]
Darkhotel's selective infector modifies executables stored on removable media as a method of spreading across computers.[8]
DustySky searches for removable media and duplicates itself onto it.[9]
FIN7 actors have mailed USB drives to potential victims containing malware that downloads and installs various backdoors, including in some cases for ransomware operations.[10]
Flame contains modules to infect USB sticks and spread laterally to other Windows systems the stick is plugged into using Autorun functionality.[11]
H1N1 has functionality to copy itself to removable media.[12]
Mustang Panda has used a customized PlugX variant which could spread through USB connections.[13]
njRAT can be configured to spread via removable drives.[14][15]
QakBot has the ability to use removable drives to spread through compromised networks.[16]
Ramsay can spread itself by infecting other portable executable files on removable drives.[17]

APT30 may have used the SHIPSHAPE malware to move onto air-gapped networks. SHIPSHAPE targets removable drives to spread to other systems by modifying the drive to use Autorun to execute or by hiding legitimate document files and copying an executable to the folder with the same name as the legitimate document.[18]
Stuxnet can propagate via removable media using an autorun.inf file or the CVE-2010-2568 LNK vulnerability.[19]
Tropic Trooper has attempted to transfer USBferry from an infected USB device by copying an Autorun function to the target machine.[20]
Unknown Logger is capable of spreading to USB devices.[21]
Ursnif has copied itself to and infected removable drives for propagation.[22][23]
USBferry can copy its installer to attached USB storage devices.[20]
USBStealer drops itself onto removable media and relies on Autorun to execute the malicious file when a user opens the removable media on another system.[24]
APT18 actors leverage legitimate credentials to log into external remote services.[5]
APT28 has used Tor and a variety of commercial VPN services to route brute force authentication attempts.[6]
APT29 has used compromised identities to access networks via SSH, VPNs, and other remote access tools.[7][8][9]
APT41 compromised an online billing/payment service using VPN access between a third-party service provider and the targeted payment service.[10]
Chimera has used legitimate credentials to login to an external VPN, Citrix, SSH, and other remote services.[11][12]
Doki was executed through an open Docker daemon API port.[13]
Dragonfly has used VPNs and Outlook Web Access (OWA) to maintain access to victim networks.[14][15]
FIN5 has used legitimate VPN, Citrix, or VNC credentials to maintain access to a victim environment.[16][17][18]
GALLIUM has used VPN services, including SoftEther VPN, to access and maintain persistence in victim environments.[19][20]
GOLD SOUTHFIELD has used publicly-accessible RDP and remote management and monitoring (RMM) servers to gain access to victim machines.[21]
Hildegard was executed through an unsecure kubelet that allowed anonymous access to the victim environment.[4]
Ke3chang has gained access through VPNs including with compromised accounts and stolen VPN certificates.[22][23]
Kimsuky has used RDP to establish persistence.[24]
Kinsing was executed in an Ubuntu container deployed via an open Docker daemon API.[25]
Leviathan has used external remote services such as virtual private networks (VPN) to gain initial access.[26]
Linux Rabbit attempts to gain access to the server via SSH.[27]
Night Dragon has used compromised VPN accounts to gain access to victim systems.[28]
OilRig uses remote services such as VPN, Citrix, or OWA to persist in an environment.[29]
Operation Wocao has used stolen credentials to connect to the victim's network via VPN.[30]

Sandworm Team has used Dropbear SSH with a hardcoded backdoor password to maintain persistence within the target network. Sandworm Team has also used VPN tunnels established in legitimate software company infrastructure to gain access to internal networks of that software company's users.[31][32][33]

TeamTNT has used open-source tools such as Weave Scope to target exposed Docker API ports and gain initial access to victim environments.[34] TeamTNT has also targeted exposed kubelets for Kubernetes environments.[4]
TEMP.Veles has used a VPN to persist in the victim environment.[35]

Threat Group-3390 actors look for and use VPN profiles during an operation to access the network using external VPN services.[36] Threat Group-3390 has also obtained OWA account credentials during intrusions that it subsequently used to attempt to regain access when evicted from a victim network.[37]
Wizard Spider has accessed victim networks by using stolen credentials to access the corporate VPN infrastructure.[38]
Andariel has used watering hole attacks, often with zero-day exploits, to gain initial access to victims within a specific IP range.[3][4]
APT19 performed a watering hole attack on forbes.com in 2014 to compromise targets.[5]
APT28 has compromised targets via strategic web compromise utilizing custom exploit kits.[6]
APT32 has infected victims by tricking them into visiting compromised watering hole websites.[7][8]

APT37 has used strategic web compromises, particularly of South Korean websites, to distribute malware. The group has also used torrent file-sharing sites to more indiscriminately disseminate malware to victims. As part of their compromises, the group has used a Javascript based profiler called RICECURRY to profile a victim's web browser and deliver malicious code accordingly.[9][10][11]
APT38 has conducted watering holes schemes to gain initial access to victims.[12][13]
Axiom has used watering hole attacks to gain access.[14]
Bad Rabbit spread through watering holes on popular sites by injecting JavaScript into the HTML body or a .js file.[15][16]
BRONZE BUTLER compromised three Japanese websites using a Flash exploit to perform watering hole attacks.[17]
Bundlore has been spread through malicious advertisements on websites.[18]
Dark Caracal leveraged a watering hole to serve up malicious code.[19]
Darkhotel used embedded iframes on hotel login portals to redirect selected victims to download malware.[20]
Dragonfly has compromised targets via strategic web compromise (SWC) utilizing a custom exploit kit.[21][22][23]
Elderwood has delivered zero-day exploits and malware to victims by injecting malicious code into specific public Web pages visited by targets within a particular sector.[24][25][26]
Grandoreiro has used compromised websites and Google Ads to bait victims into downloading its installer.[27][28]
KARAE was distributed through torrent file-sharing websites to South Korean victims, using a YouTube video downloader application as a lure.[10]
Lazarus Group delivered RATANKBA and other malicious code to victims via a compromised legitimate website.[29][30]
Leafminer has infected victims using watering holes.[31]
Leviathan has infected victims using watering holes.[32]
LoudMiner is typically bundled with pirated copies of Virtual Studio Technology (VST) for Windows and macOS.[33]
Machete has distributed Machete through a fake blog website.[34]
Magic Hound has conducted watering-hole attacks through media and magazine websites.[35]
Patchwork has used watering holes to deliver files with exploits to initial victims.[36][37]
PLATINUM has sometimes used drive-by attacks against vulnerable browser plugins.[38]
POORAIM has been delivered through compromised sites acting as watering holes.[10]
PROMETHIUM has used watering hole attacks to deliver malicious versions of legitimate installers.[39]
REvil has infected victim machines through compromised websites and exploit kits.[40][41][42][43]
RTM has distributed its malware via the RIG and SUNDOWN exploit kits, as well as online advertising network Yandex.Direct.[44][45]
Threat Group-3390 has extensively used strategic web compromises to target victims.[46][47]
Transparent Tribe has used websites with malicious hyperlinks and iframes to infect targeted victims with Crimson, njRAT, and other malicious tools.[48][49][50]
Turla has infected victims using watering holes.[51][52]
Windigo has distributed Windows malware via drive-by downloads.[53]
Windshift has used compromised websites to register custom URL schemes on a remote system.[54]

APT28 has used a variety of public exploits, including CVE 2020-0688 and CVE 2020-17144, to gain execution on vulnerable Microsoft Exchange; they have also conducted SQL injection attacks against external websites.[8][9]

APT29 has exploited CVE-2019-19781 for Citrix, CVE-2019-11510 for Pulse Secure VPNs, CVE-2018-13379 for FortiGate VPNs, and CVE-2019-9670 in Zimbra software to gain access. They have also exploited CVE-2020-0688 against the Microsoft Exchange Control Panel to regain access to a network.[10][11][12]
APT39 has used SQL injection for initial compromise.[13]
APT41 exploited CVE-2020-10189 against Zoho ManageEngine Desktop Central, and CVE-2019-19781 to compromise Citrix Application Delivery Controllers (ADC) and gateway devices.[14]
Axiom has been observed using SQL injection to gain access to systems.[15][16]
BackdoorDiplomacy has exploited CVE-2020-5902, an F5 BIP-IP vulnerability, to drop a Linux backdoor. BackdoorDiplomacy has also exploited mis-configured Plesk servers.[17]
BlackTech has exploited a buffer overflow vulnerability in Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS) 6.0, CVE-2017-7269, in order to establish a new HTTP or command and control (C2) server.[18]
Blue Mockingbird has gained initial access by exploiting CVE-2019-18935, a vulnerability within Telerik UI for ASP.NET AJAX.[19]
Dragonfly has conducted SQL injection attacks, exploited vulnerabilities CVE-2019-19781 and CVE-2020-0688 for Citrix and MS Exchange, and CVE-2018-13379 for Fortinet VPNs.[20]
Fox Kitten has exploited known vulnerabilities in Fortinet, PulseSecure, and Palo Alto VPN appliances.[21][22][23][24][25]
GALLIUM exploited a publicly-facing servers including Wildfly/JBoss servers to gain access to the network.[26][27]
GOLD SOUTHFIELD has exploited Oracle WebLogic vulnerabilities for initial compromise.[28]

HAFNIUM has exploited CVE-2021-26855, CVE-2021-26857, CVE-2021-26858, and CVE-2021-27065 to compromise on-premises versions of Microsoft Exchange Server, enabling access to email accounts and installation of additional malware.[29][30][31]
Havij is used to automate SQL injection.[32]
Ke3chang has compromised networks by exploiting Internet-facing applications, including vulnerable Microsoft Exchange and SharePoint servers.[33]
Kimsuky has exploited various vulnerabilities for initial access, including Microsoft Exchange vulnerability CVE-2020-0688.[34]
Magic Hound has used open-source JNDI exploit kits to leverage the Log4j (CVE-2021-44228) vulnerability.[35]
menuPass has leveraged vulnerabilities in Pulse Secure VPNs to hijack sessions.[36]
Night Dragon has performed SQL injection attacks of extranet web servers to gain access.[37]
Operation Wocao has gained initial access via vulnerable webservers.[38]
Rocke exploited Apache Struts, Oracle WebLogic (CVE-2017-10271), and Adobe ColdFusion (CVE-2017-3066) vulnerabilities to deliver malware.[39][40]
Siloscape is executed after the attacker gains initial access to a Windows container using a known vulnerability.[41]
SoreFang can gain access by exploiting a Sangfor SSL VPN vulnerability that allows for the placement and delivery of malicious update binaries.[42]
sqlmap can be used to automate exploitation of SQL injection vulnerabilities.[43]
Threat Group-3390 has exploited the Microsoft SharePoint vulnerability CVE-2019-0604 and CVE-2021-26855, CVE-2021-26857, CVE-2021-26858, and CVE-2021-27065 in Exchange Server.[44]
Volatile Cedar has targeted publicly facing web servers, with both automatic and manual vulnerability discovery.[45] [46]
ZxShell has been dropped through exploitation of CVE-2011-2462, CVE-2013-3163, and CVE-2014-0322.[47]

XCSSET adds malicious code to a host's Xcode projects by enumerating CocoaPods target_integrator.rb files under the /Library/Ruby/Gems folder or enumerates all .xcodeproj folders under a given directory. XCSSET then downloads a script and Mach-O file into the Xcode project folder.[2]
APT29 gained initial network access to some victims via a trojanized update of SolarWinds Orion software.[3][4][5][6]
APT41 gained access to production environments where they could inject malicious code into legitimate, signed files and widely distribute them to end users.[7]
CCBkdr was added to a legitimate, signed version 5.33 of the CCleaner software and distributed on CCleaner's distribution site.[8][9][1]
Cobalt Group has compromised legitimate web browser updates to deliver a backdoor. [10]
Dragonfly has placed trojanized installers for control system software on legitimate vendor app stores.[11][12]
GOLD SOUTHFIELD has distributed ransomware by backdooring software installers via a strategic web compromise of the site hosting Italian WinRAR.[13][14][15]
GoldenSpy has been packaged with a legitimate tax preparation software.[16]
Sandworm Team has distributed NotPetya by compromising the legitimate Ukrainian accounting software M.E.Doc and replacing a legitimate software update with a malicious one.[17][18][19]
SUNSPOT malware was designed and used to insert SUNBURST into software builds of the SolarWinds Orion IT management product.[20]
Threat Group-3390 has compromised the Able Desktop installer to gain access to victim's environments.[21]
Once APT28 gained access to the DCCC network, the group then proceeded to use that access to compromise the DNC network.[2]
APT29 has gained access through compromised accounts at cloud solution partners, and used compromised certificates issued by Mimecast to authenticate to Mimecast customer systems.[3][4][5]
GOLD SOUTHFIELD has breached Managed Service Providers (MSP's) to deliver malware to MSP customers.[6]
menuPass has used legitimate access granted to Managed Service Providers in order to access victims of interest.[7][8][9][10][11]
Sandworm Team has used dedicated network connections from one victim organization to gain unauthorized access to a separate organization.[12]
Threat Group-3390 has compromised third party service providers to gain access to victim's environments.[13]
DarkVishnya used Bash Bunny, Raspberry Pi, netbooks or inexpensive laptops to connect to the companyâ€™s local network.[5]
admin@338 has sent emails with malicious Microsoft Office documents attached.[1]
The primary delivered mechaism for Agent Tesla is through email phishing messages.[2]
Ajax Security Team has used personalized spearphishing attachments.[3]
Andariel has conducted spearphishing campaigns that included malicious Word or Excel attachments.[4][5]
AppleSeed has been distributed to victims through malicious e-mail attachments.[6]
APT-C-36 has used spearphishing emails with password protected RAR attachment to avoid being detected by the email gateway.[7]
APT1 has sent spearphishing emails containing malicious attachments.[8]
APT12 has sent emails with malicious Microsoft Office documents and PDFs attached.[9][10]
APT19 sent spearphishing emails with malicious attachments in RTF and XLSM formats to deliver initial exploits.[11]
APT28 sent spearphishing emails containing malicious Microsoft Office and RAR attachments.[12][13][14][15][16][17][18][19]
APT29 has used spearphishing emails with an attachment to deliver files with exploits to initial victims.[20][21][22][23][24][25]
APT30 has used spearphishing emails with malicious DOC attachments.[26]
APT32 has sent spearphishing emails with a malicious executable disguised as a document or spreadsheet.[27][28][29][30][31][32]
APT33 has sent spearphishing e-mails with archive attachments.[33]
APT37 delivers malware using spearphishing emails with malicious HWP attachments.[34][35][36]
APT38 has conducted spearphishing campaigns using malicious email attachments.[37]
APT39 leveraged spearphishing emails with malicious attachments to initially compromise victims.[38][39][40]
APT41 sent spearphishing emails with attachments such as compiled HTML (.chm) files to initially compromise their victims.[41]
BADFLICK has been distributed via spearphishing campaigns containing malicious Microsoft Word documents.[42]
Bandook is delivered via a malicious Word document inside a zip file.[43]
Bisonal has been delivered as malicious email attachments.[44]
BlackTech has used spearphishing e-mails with malicious password-protected archived files (ZIP or RAR) to deliver malware.[45][46]
BLINDINGCAN has been delivered by phishing emails containing malicious Microsoft Office documents.[47]
BRONZE BUTLER used spearphishing emails with malicious Microsoft Word attachments to infect victims.[48][49]
Chaes has been delivered by sending victims a phishing email containing a malicious .docx file.[50]
Clambling has been delivered to victim's machines through malicious e-mail attachments.[51]

Cobalt Group has sent spearphishing emails with various attachment types to corporate and personal email accounts of victim organizations. Attachment types have included .rtf, .doc, .xls, archives containing LNK files, and password protected archives containing .exe and .scr executables.[52][53][54][55][56][57][58][59]
Confucius has crafted and sent victims malicious attachments to gain initial access.[60]
Darkhotel has sent spearphishing emails with malicious RAR and .LNK attachments.[61][62]

DarkHydrus has sent spearphishing emails with password-protected RAR archives containing malicious Excel Web Query files (.iqy). The group has also sent spearphishing emails that contained malicious Microsoft Office documents that use the "attachedTemplate" technique to load a template from a remote server.[63][64][65]
DarkWatchman has been delivered via spearphishing emails that contain a malicious zip file.[66]
Dragonfly has sent emails with malicious attachments to gain initial access.[67]
Elderwood has delivered zero-day exploits and malware to victims via targeted emails containing malicious attachments.[68][69]
Emotet has been delivered by phishing emails containing attachments. [70][71][72][73][74][75][76][77][78]
EnvyScout has been distributed via spearphishing as an email attachment.[79]
Ferocious Kitten has conducted spearphishing campaigns containing malicious documents to lure victims to open the attachments.[80]
FIN4 has used spearphishing emails containing attachments (which are often stolen, legitimate documents sent from compromised accounts) with embedded malicious macros.[81][82]
FIN6 has targeted victims with e-mails containing malicious attachments.[83]
FIN7 sent spearphishing emails with either malicious Microsoft Documents or RTF files attached.[84][85][86][87][88]
FIN8 has distributed targeted emails containing Word documents with embedded malicious macros.[89][90][91]
Flagpro has been distributed via spearphishing as an email attachment.[46]
Frankenstein has used spearphishing emails to send trojanized Microsoft Word documents.[92]
Gallmaker sent emails with malicious Microsoft Office documents attached.[93]
Gamaredon Group has delivered spearphishing emails with malicious attachments to targets.[94][95][96][97][98][99]
Gorgon Group sent emails to victims with malicious Microsoft Office documents attached.[100]
Hancitor has been delivered via phishing emails with malicious attachments.[101]
Higaisa has sent spearphishing emails containing malicious attachments.[102][103]
IcedID has been delivered via phishing e-mails with malicious attachments.[104]
Inception has used weaponized documents attached to spearphishing emails for reconnaissance and initial compromise.[105][106][107][108]
IndigoZebra sent spearphishing emails containing malicious password-protected RAR attachments.[109][110]
Javali has been delivered as malicious e-mail attachments.[111]
JSS Loader has been delivered by phishing emails containing malicious Microsoft Excel attachments.[87]
Kerrdown has been distributed through malicious e-mail attachments.[32]
Kimsuky has used emails containing Word, Excel and/or HWP (Hangul Word Processor) documents in their spearphishing campaigns.[112][113][114][115][116][6][117][118]
KOCTOPUS has been distributed via spearphishing emails with malicious attachments.[119]
KONNI has been delivered via spearphishing campaigns through a malicious Word document.[120]
Lazarus Group has targeted victims with spearphishing emails containing malicious Microsoft Word documents.[121][122][123][124][125]
LazyScripter has used spam emails weaponized with archive or document files as its initial infection vector.[119]
Leviathan has sent spearphishing emails with malicious attachments, including .rtf, .doc, and .xls files.[126][127]
Lokibot is delivered via a malicious XLS attachment contained within a spearhpishing email.[128]
Machete has delivered spearphishing emails that contain a zipped file with malicious contents.[129][130][131]
menuPass has sent malicious Office documents via email as part of spearphishing campaigns as well as executables disguised as documents.[132][133][134][135]
Metamorfo has been delivered to victims via emails with malicious HTML attachments.[136][137]
Mofang delivered spearphishing emails with malicious documents, PDFs, or Excel files attached.[138]
Molerats has sent phishing emails with malicious Microsoft Word and PDF attachments.[139][140][141]
MuddyWater has compromised third parties and used compromised accounts to send spearphishing emails with targeted attachments to recipients.[142][143][144][145][146][147]
Mustang Panda has used spearphishing attachments to deliver initial access payloads.[148][149][150]
Naikon has used malicious e-mail attachments to deliver malware.[151]
NETWIRE has been spread via e-mail campaigns utilizing malicious attachments.[152][153]
Nomadic Octopus has targeted victims with spearphishing emails containing malicious attachments.[154][155]
OceanSalt has been delivered via spearphishing emails with Microsoft Office attachments.[156]
Octopus has been delivered via spearsphishing emails.[155]
OilRig has sent spearphising emails with malicious attachments to potential victims using compromised and/or spoofed email accounts.[157][158][159]
Patchwork has used spearphishing with an attachment to deliver files with exploits to initial victims.[160][161][162][163]
PLATINUM has sent spearphishing emails with attachments to victims as its primary initial access vector.[164]
PoetRAT was distributed via malicious Word documents.[165]
Pony has been delivered via spearphishing attachments.[166]
QakBot has spread through emails with malicious attachments.[167][168][169][170][171][172][173]
Ramsay has been distributed through spearphishing emails with malicious attachments.[174]
Rancor has attached a malicious document to an email to gain initial access.[175]
REvil has been distributed via malicious e-mail attachments including MS Word Documents.[176][177][178][179][180]
Rifdoor has been distributed in e-mails with malicious Excel or Word documents.[181]
ROKRAT has been delivered via spearphishing emails that contain a malicious Hangul Office or Microsoft Word document.[182]
RTM has been delivered via spearphishing attachments disguised as PDF documents.[183]
RTM has used spearphishing attachments to distribute its malware.[184]
Sandworm Team has delivered malicious Microsoft Office attachments via spearphishing emails.[185][186][187][188]
Sharpshooter has sent malicious attachments via emails to targets.[189]
Sidewinder has sent e-mails with malicious attachments often crafted for specific targets.[190]
Silence has sent emails with malicious DOCX, CHM, LNK and ZIP attachments. [191][192][193]
TA459 has targeted victims using spearphishing emails with malicious Microsoft Word attachments.[194]
TA505 has used spearphishing emails with malicious attachments to initially compromise victims.[195][196][197][198][199][200][201][202][203]
TA551 has sent spearphishing attachments with password protected ZIP files.[204][205][206]
Taidoor has been delivered through spearphishing emails.[207]
The White Company has sent phishing emails with malicious Microsoft Word attachments to victims.[208]
Threat Group-3390 has used e-mail to deliver malicious attachments to victims.[51]
ThreatNeedle has been distributed via a malicious Word document within a spearphishing email.[122]
Tonto Team has delivered payloads via spearphishing attachments.[209]
Transparent Tribe has sent spearphishing e-mails with attachments to deliver malicious payloads.[210][211][212][213][214]
TrickBot has used an email with an Excel sheet containing a malicious macro to deploy the malware[215]
Tropic Trooper sent spearphishing emails that contained malicious Microsoft Office and fake installer file attachments.[216][217][218][219][220]
Valak has been delivered via spearphishing e-mails with password protected ZIP files.[204]
WarzoneRAT has been distributed as a malicious attachment within an email.[221][60]
Windshift has sent spearphishing emails with attachment to harvest credentials and deliver malware.[222]
WIRTE has sent emails to intended victims with malicious MS Word and Excel attachments.[223]
Wizard Spider has used spearphishing attachments to deliver Microsoft documents containing macros or PDFs containing malicious links to download either Emotet, Bokbot, TrickBot, or Bazar.[224][225]
AADInternals can send "consent phishing" emails containing malicious links designed to steal usersâ€?access tokens.[3]
AppleJeus has been distributed via spearphishing link.[4]
APT1 has sent spearphishing emails containing hyperlinks to malicious files.[5]

Wizard Spider has established persistence using Userinit by adding the Registry key HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon.[12]
Empire can enumerate Security Support Providers (SSPs) as well as utilize PowerSploit's Install-SSP and Invoke-Mimikatz to install malicious SSPs and log authentication events.[2]

InvisiMole can use a .lnk shortcut for the Control Panel to establish persistence.[19]

xCaon has added persistence via the Registry key HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Windows\load which causes the malware to run each time any user logs in.[6]
Bonadan has maliciously altered the OpenSSH binary on targeted systems to create a backdoor.[1]
Ebury has been embedded into modified OpenSSH binaries to gain persistent access to SSH credential information.[2]
Industroyer has used a Trojanized version of the Windows Notepad application for an additional backdoor persistence mechanism.[3]
Kessel has maliciously altered the OpenSSH binary on targeted systems to create a backdoor.[1]
Kobalos replaced the SSH client with a trojanized SSH client to steal credentials on compromised systems.[4]

ThiefQuest searches through the /Users/ folder looking for executable files. For each executable, ThiefQuest prepends a copy of itself to the beginning of the file. When the file is executed, the ThiefQuest code is executed first. ThiefQuest creates a hidden file, copies the original target executable to the file, then executes the new hidden file to maintain the appearance of normal behavior. [5][6]
XCSSET uses a malicious browser application to replace the legitimate browser in order to continuously capture credentials, monitor web traffic, and download additional modules.[7]
Chimera's malware has altered the NTLM authentication program on domain controllers to allow Chimera to login without a valid credential.[2]

Skeleton Key is used to patch an enterprise domain controller authentication process with a backdoor password. It allows adversaries to bypass the standard authentication system to use a defined password for all accounts authenticating to that domain controller.[1]
Remsec harvests plain-text credentials as a password filter registered on domain controllers.[2]

Strider has registered its persistence module on domain controllers as a Windows LSA (Local System Authority) password filter to acquire credentials any time a domain, local user, or administrator logs in or changes a password.[2]
Ebury can deactivate PAM modules to tamper with the sshd configuration.[6]
Skidmap has the ability to replace the pam_unix.so file on an infected machine with its own malicious version that accepts a specific backdoor password for all users.[7]

Ebury can intercept private keys using a trojanized ssh-add function.[1]
Kessel has trojanized the ssh_login and user-auth_pubkey functions to steal plaintext credentials.[2]
SILENTTRINITY can create a backdoor in KeePass using a malicious config file and in TortoiseSVN using a registry hook.[3]

menuPass has used DLL search order hijacking.[25]

RDAT can also embed data within a BMP image prior to exfiltration.[20]
RegDuke can hide data in images, including use of the Least Significant Bit (LSB).[12]
TA551 has hidden encoded data for malware DLLs in a PNG.[21]
Tropic Trooper has used JPG files with encrypted payloads to mask their backdoor routines and evade detection.[22]
Cardinal RAT and its watchdog component are compiled and executed after being delivered to victims as embedded, uncompiled source code.[3]
DarkWatchman has used the csc.exe tool to compile a C
FoggyWeb can compile and execute source code sent to the compromised AD FS server via a specific HTTP POST.[5]
Gamaredon Group has compiled the source code for a downloader directly on the infected system using the built-in Microsoft.CSharp.CSharpCodeProvider class.[6]
MuddyWater has used the .NET csc.exe tool to compile executables from downloaded C
njRAT has used AutoIt to compile the payload and main script into a single executable after delivery.[7]
Rocke has compiled malware, delivered to victims as .c files, with the GNU Compiler Collection (GCC).[8]
APT3 has been known to remove indicators of compromise from tools.[1]
Cobalt Strike includes a capability to modify the Beacon payload to eliminate known signatures or unpacking methods.[2][3]
Analysis of Daserf has shown that it regularly undergoes technical improvements to evade anti-virus detection.[4]
Deep Panda has updated and modified its malware, resulting in different hash values that evade detection.[5]
GALLIUM ensured each payload had a unique hash, including by using different types of packers.[6]
The author of GravityRAT submitted samples to VirusTotal for testing, showing that the author modified the code to try to hide the DDE object in a different part of the document.[7]
InvisiMole has undergone regular technical improvements in an attempt to evade detection.[8]
OilRig has tested malware samples to determine AV detection and subsequently modified the samples to ensure AV evasion.[9][10]
Operation Wocao has edited variable names within the Impacket suite to avoid automated detection.[11]
Patchwork apparently altered NDiskMonitor samples by adding four bytes of random letters in a likely attempt to change the file hashes.[12]
Penquin can remove strings from binaries.[13]
PowerSploit's Find-AVSignature AntivirusBypass module can be used to locate single byte anti-virus signatures.[14][15]
QakBot can make small changes to itself in order to change its checksum and hash value.[16][17]
SUNBURST source code used generic variable names and pre-obfuscated strings, and was likely sanitized of developer comments before being added to SUNSPOT.[18]
TEMP.Veles has modified files based on the open-source project cryptcat in an apparent attempt to decrease AV detection rates.[19]
Based on comparison of Gazer versions, Turla made an effort to obfuscate strings in the malware that could be used as IoCs, including the mutex name and named pipe.[20]
Waterbear can scramble functions not to be executed again with random values.[21]
APT29 has embedded an ISO file within an HTML attachment that contained JavaScript code to initiate malware execution.[5]
EnvyScout contains JavaScript code that can extract an encoded blob from its HTML body and write it to disk.[6]

Most of the strings in ADVSTORESHELL are encrypted with an XOR-based algorithm; some strings are also encrypted with 3DES and reversed. API function names are also reversed, presumably to avoid detection in memory.[7][8]
Agent Tesla has had its code obfuscated in an apparent attempt to make analysis difficult.[9] Agent Tesla has used the Rijndael symmetric encryption algorithm to encrypt strings.[10]
Anchor has obfuscated code with stack strings and string encryption.[11]
AppleJeus has XOR-encrypted collected system information prior to sending to a C2. AppleJeus has also used the open source ADVObfuscation library for its components.[12]
AppleSeed has the ability to Base64 encode its payload and custom encrypt API calls.[13]
APT-C-36 has used ConfuserEx to obfuscate its variant of Imminent Monitor, compressed payload and RAT packages, and password protected encrypted email attachments to avoid detection.[14]
APT18 obfuscates strings in the payload.[15]
APT19 used Base64 to obfuscate commands and the payload.[16]
APT28 encrypted a .dll payload using RTL and a custom encryption algorithm. APT28 has also obfuscated payloads with base64, XOR, and RC4.[8][17][18][19][20]
APT29 has used encoded PowerShell commands.[21]
APT3 obfuscates files or information to help evade defensive measures.[22]

APT32 uses the Invoke-Obfuscation framework to obfuscate their PowerShell and also performs other code obfuscation. APT32 has also encoded payloads using Base64 and a framework called "Dont-Kill-My-Cat (DKMC). APT32 also encrypts the library used for network exfiltration with AES-256 in CBC mode in their macOS backdoor.[23][24][25][26][27][28][29]
APT33 has used base64 to encode payloads.[30]
APT37 obfuscates strings and payloads.[31][32][33]
APT39 has used malware to drop encrypted CAB files.[34]

Aquatic Panda has encoded commands in Base64.[36]
Aria-body has used an encrypted configuration file for its loader.[37]
Astaroth obfuscates its JScript code, and has used an XOR-based algorithm to encrypt payloads twice with different keys.[38][39]

Strings in Attor's components are encrypted with a XOR cipher, using a hardcoded key and the configuration data, log files and plugins are encrypted using a hybrid encryption scheme of Blowfish-OFB combined with RSA.[40]
AuditCred encrypts the configuration.[41]
Avaddon has used encrypted strings.[42]
Avenger has the ability to XOR encrypt files to be sent to C2.[43]
BackConfig has used compressed and decimal encoded VBS scripts.[44]
BackdoorDiplomacy has obfuscated tools and malware it uses with VMProtect.[45]
Bazar has used XOR, RSA2, and RC4 encrypted files.[46][47][48]

BLINDINGCAN has obfuscated code using Base64 encoding.[54]

BLUELIGHT has a XOR-encoded payload.[56]
BoomBox can encrypt data using AES prior to exfiltration.[57]
BOOSTWRITE has encoded its payloads using a ChaCha stream cipher with a 256-bit key and 64-bit Initialization vector (IV) to evade detection.[58]

Bundlore has obfuscated data with base64, AES, RC4, and bz2.[60]
Carbanak encrypts strings to make analysis more difficult.[61]

Carbon encrypts configuration files and tasks for the malware to complete using CAST-128 algorithm.[63][64]
Cardinal RAT encodes many of its artifacts and is encrypted (AES-128) when downloaded.[65]
CARROTBALL has used a custom base64 alphabet to decode files.[66]
CARROTBAT has the ability to download a base64 encoded payload and execute obfuscated commands on the infected host.[67]
Chimera has encoded PowerShell commands.[68]
Chrommme can encrypt sections of its code to evade detection.[69]
The Clambling executable has been obfuscated when dropped on a compromised host.[70]
Cobalt Group obfuscated several scriptlets and code used on the victimâ€™s machine, including through use of XOR and RC4.[71][72]
Cobalt Strike can hash functions to obfuscate calls to the Windows API and use a public/private key pair to encrypt Beacon session metadata.[73][74]
CoinTicker initially downloads a hidden encoded file.[75]
Comnie uses RC4 and Base64 to obfuscate strings.[76]

ComRAT has used encryption and base64 to obfuscate its orchestrator code in the Registry. ComRAT has also embedded an XOR encrypted communications module inside the orchestrator module. ComRAT has encrypted its virtual file system using AES-256 in XTS mode and has encoded PowerShell scripts.[77][78]
Conficker has obfuscated its code to prevent its removal from host machines.[79]
Conti can use compiler-based obfuscation for its code, encrypt DLLs, and hide Windows API calls.[80][81][48]
CookieMiner has used base64 encoding to obfuscate scripts on the system.[82]
CORESHELL obfuscates strings using a custom stream cipher.[83]
The payload of CozyCar is encrypted with simple XOR with a rotating key. The CozyCar configuration file has been encrypted with RC4 keys.[84]
Cuba has used multiple layers of obfuscation to avoid analysis, including its Base64 encoded payload.[85]
Dacls can encrypt its configuration file with AES CBC.[86]
Dark Caracal has obfuscated strings in Bandook by base64 encoding, and then encrypting them.[87]
Darkhotel has obfuscated code using RC4, XOR, and RSA.[88][89]
DarkWatchman has used Base64 to encode PowerShell commands. DarkWatchman has been delivered as compressed RAR payloads in ZIP files to victims.[90]
Daserf uses encrypted Windows APIs and also encrypts data using the alternative base64+RC4 or the Caesar cipher.[91]
Denis obfuscates its code and encrypts the API names. Denis also encodes its payload in Base64.[92][27]
Diavol has Base64 encoded the RSA public key used for encrypting files.[93]
DOGCALL is encrypted using single-byte XOR.[94]
Donut can generate encrypted, compressed/encoded, or otherwise obfuscated code modules.[95]
DRATzarus can be partly encrypted with XOR.[96]
Dridex's strings are obfuscated using RC4.[97]
Drovorub has used XOR encrypted payloads in WebSocket client to server messages.[98]

Ebury has obfuscated its strings with a simple XOR encryption with a static key.[102]
ECCENTRICBANDWAGON has encrypted strings with RC4.[103]

Elderwood has encrypted documents and malicious executables.[106]

Emotet has obfuscated macros within malicious documents to hide the URLs hosting the malware, CMD.exe arguments, and PowerShell scripts. [110][111][112][113]

EnvyScout can Base64 encode payloads.[57]

The FIVEHANDS payload is encrypted with AES-128.[128][129][130]

Gazer logs its actions into files that are encrypted with 3DES. It also uses RSA to encrypt resources.[145]
Gelsemium has the ability to compress its components.[69]

jRATâ€™s Java payload is encrypted with AES.[187] Additionally, backdoor files are encrypted using DES as a stream cipher. Later variants of jRAT also incorporated AV evasion methods such as Java bytecode obfuscation via the commercial Allatori obfuscation tool.[188]

Kazuar is obfuscated using the open source ConfuserEx protector. Kazuar also obfuscates the name of created files/folders/mutexes and encrypts debug messages written to log files using the Rijndael cipher.[189]

KOCTOPUS has obfuscated scripts with the BatchEncryption tool.[200]

Kwampirs downloads additional files that are base64-encoded and encrypted with another cipher.[202]

Lazarus Group has used multiple types of encryption and encoding for their payloads, including AES, Caracachs, RC4, XOR, Base64, and other tricks such as creating aliases in code for Native API function names.[203][204][205][206][86][207][208][209][96][210][211]
LazyScripter has leveraged the BatchEncryption tool to perform advanced batch obfuscation and encoding techniques.[200]

LightNeuron encrypts its configuration files with AES-256.[214]

Matryoshka obfuscates API function names using a substitute cipher combined with Base64 encoding.[220]
Maze has decrypted strings and other important information during the encryption process. Maze also calls certain functions dynamically to hinder analysis.[221]

A Threat Group-3390 tool can encrypt payloads using XOR. Threat Group-3390 malware is also obfuscated using Metasploitâ€™s shikata_ga_nai encoder as well as compressed with LZNT1 compression.[353][354][355]

TINYTYPHON has used XOR with 0x90 to obfuscate its configuration file.[357]
Torisma has been Base64 encoded and AES encrypted.[209]
Transparent Tribe has dropped encoded executables on compromised hosts.[358]
TrickBot uses non-descriptive names to hide functionality and uses an AES CBC (256 bits) encryption algorithm for its loader and configuration files.[359]
TRITON encoded the two inject.bin and imain.bin payloads.[360]
Trojan.Karagany can base64 encode and AES-128-CBC encrypt data prior to transmission.[361]
Tropic Trooper has encrypted configuration files.[362][363]
Turian can use VMProtect for obfuscation.[45]
Turla has used encryption (including salted 3DES via PowerSploit's Out-EncryptedScript.ps1), random variable names, and base64 encoding to obfuscate PowerShell commands and payloads.[276]
APIs and strings in some TYPEFRAME variants are RC4 encrypted. Another variant is encoded with XOR.[364]
UBoatRAT encrypts instructions in the payload using a simple XOR cipher.[365]

Ursnif has used an XOR-based algorithm to encrypt Tor clients dropped to disk.[366] Ursnif droppers have also been delivered as password-protected zip files that execute base64 encoded PowerShell commands.[367]
Most strings in USBStealer are encrypted using 3DES and XOR and reversed.[368]
Valak has the ability to base64 encode and XOR encrypt strings.[369][347][370]
VERMIN is obfuscated using the obfuscation tool called ConfuserEx.[371]
A Volgmer variant is encoded using a simple XOR cipher.[372]
The WastedLocker payload includes encrypted strings stored within the .bss section of the binary file.[373]
Waterbear has used RC4 encrypted shellcode and encrypted functions.[374]
WhisperGate can Base64 encode strings, store downloaded files in reverse byte order, and use the Eazfuscator tool to obfuscate its third stage.[375][376]
Whitefly has encrypted the payload used for C2.[377]
Windshift has used string encoding with floating point calculations.[378]
WindTail can be delivered as a compressed, encrypted, and encoded payload.[379]
Winnti for Linux can encode its configuration file with single-byte XOR encoding.[380]
Winnti for Windows has the ability to encrypt and compress its payload.[381]
Wizard Spider used Base64 encoding to obfuscate an Empire service and PowerShell commands.[382][383]
A version of XTunnel introduced in July 2015 obfuscated the binary using opaque predicates and other techniques in a likely attempt to obfuscate it and bypass security products.[384]
YAHOYAH encrypts its configuration file using a simple algorithm.[385]
ZeroT has encrypted its payload with RC4.[386]
Zeus Panda encrypts strings with XOR and obfuscates the macro code from the initial payload. Zeus Panda also encrypts all configuration and settings in AES and RC4.[387][388]
Zox has been encoded with Base64.[389]
APT37 has signed its malware with an invalid digital certificates listed as "Tencent Technology (Shenzhen) Company Limited."[2]
BADNEWS is sometimes signed with an invalid Authenticode certificate in an apparent effort to make it look more legitimate.[3]
Gelsemium has used unverified signatures on malicious DLLs.[4]
The NETWIRE client has been signed by fake and invalid digital certificates.[5]
Regin stage 1 modules for 64-bit systems have been found to be signed with fake certificates masquerading as originating from Microsoft Corporation and Broadcom Corporation.[6]
Windshift has used revoked certificates to sign malware.[7][8]
WindTail has been incompletely signed with revoked certificates.[7]
BlackTech has used right-to-left-override to obfuscate the filenames of malicious e-mail attachments.[4]
BRONZE BUTLER has used Right-to-Left Override to deceive victims into executing several strains of malware.[5]
Ferocious Kitten has used right-to-left override to reverse executablesâ€?names to make them appear to have different file extensions, rather than their real ones.[6]
Ke3chang has used the right-to-left override character in spearphishing attachment names to trick targets into executing .scr and .exe files.[7]
Scarlet Mimic has used the left-to-right override character in self-extracting RAR archive spearphishing attachment file names.[8]
APT32 has moved and renamed pubprn.vbs to a .txt file to avoid detection.[4]

The CozyCar dropper has masqueraded a copy of the infected system's rundll32.exe executable that was moved to the malware's install directory and renamed according to a predefined configuration file.[3]
GALLIUM used a renamed cmd.exe file to evade detection.[5]
Lazarus Group has renamed system utilities such as wscript.exe and mshta.exe.[6]
menuPass has renamed certutil and moved it to a different location on the system to avoid detection based on use of the tool.[7]
APT-C-36 has disguised its scheduled tasks as those used by Google.[5]

Bazar can create a task named to appear benign.[11]
build_downer has added itself to the Registry Run key as "NVIDIA" to appear legitimate.[12]

Crutch has established persistence with a scheduled task impersonating the Outlook item finder.[16]
CSPY Downloader has attempted to appear as a legitimate Windows service with a fake description claiming it is used to support packed applications.[17]
Egregor has masqueraded the svchost.exe process to exfiltrate data.[18]
The Exaramel for Windows dropper creates and starts a Windows service named wsmprovav with the description "Windows Check AV" in an apparent attempt to masquerade as a legitimate service.[19]

KillDisk registers as a service under the Plug-And-Play Support name.[32]
Kimsuky has disguised services to appear as benign software or related to operating system functions.[33]
KONNI has pretended to be the xmlProv Network Provisioning service.[34]
Kwampirs establishes persistence by adding a new service with the display name "WMI Performance Adapter Extension" in an attempt to masquerade as a legitimate WMI service.[35]
Lazarus Group has used a scheduled task named SRCheck to mask the execution of a malicious .dll.[36]
Machete renamed task names to masquerade as legitimate Google Chrome, Java, Dropbox, Adobe Reader and Python tasks.[37]

Frankenstein has used trojanized documents that retrieve remote templates from an adversary-controlled website.[15]

CaddyWiper can modify ACL entries to take ownership of files.[6]

WannaCry uses attrib +h and icacls . /grant Everyone:F /T /C /Q to make some of its files hidden and grant all users full access controls.[10]

APT41 has encrypted payloads using the Data Protection API (DPAPI), which relies on keys tied to specific user accounts on specific machines. APT41 has also environmentally keyed second stage malware with an RC5 key derived in part from the infected system's volume serial number.[8]
Equation has been observed utilizing environmental keying in payload delivery.[2][9]

InvisiMole can use Data Protection API to encrypt its components on the victimâ€™s computer, to evade detection, and to make sure the payload can only be decrypted and loaded on one specific compromised computer.[10]
PowerPunch can use the volume serial number from a target host to generate a unique XOR key for the next stage payload.[11]
ROKRAT relies on a specific victim hostname to execute and decrypt important strings.[12]
The Winnti for Windows dropper component can verify the existence of a single command line parameter and either terminate if it is not found or later use it as a decryption key.[13]
Anchor can terminate itself if specific execution flags are not present.[3]
BitPaymer compares file names and paths to a list of excluded names and directory names during encryption.[4]
BoomBox can check its current working directory and for the presence of a specific file and terminate if specific values are not found.[5]
EnvyScout can call window.location.pathname to ensure that embedded files are being executed from the C: drive, and will terminate if they are not.[5]
NativeZone can check for the presence of KM.EkeyAlmaz1C.dll and will halt execution unless it is in the same directory as the rest of the malware's components.[5][6]
Stuxnet checks for specific operating systems on 32-bit machines, Registry keys, and dates for vulnerabilities, and will exit execution if the values are not met.[7]
SUNSPOT only replaces SolarWinds Orion source code if the MD5 checksums of both the original source code file and backdoored replacement source code match hardcoded values.[8]
Torisma is only delivered to a compromised host if the victim's IP address is on an allow-list.[9]
VaporRage has the ability to check for the presence of a specific DLL and terminate if it is not found.[5]
Astaroth can check for Windows product ID's used by sandboxes and usernames and disk serial numbers associated with analyst environments.[4]
Attor can detect whether it is executed in some virtualized or emulated environment by searching for specific artifacts, such as communication with I/O ports and using VM-specific instructions.[5]
BadPatch attempts to detect if it is being run in a Virtual Machine (VM) using a WMI query for disk drive name, BIOS, and motherboard information. [6]
BLUELIGHT can check to see if the infected machine has VM tools running.[7]
CSPY Downloader can search loaded modules, PEB structure, file paths, Registry keys, and memory to determine if it is being debugged or running in a virtual environment.[8]

Darkhotel malware has used a series of checks to determine if it's being analyzed; checks include the length of executable names, if a filename ends with .Md5.exe, and if the program is executed from the root of the C:\ drive, as well as checks for sandbox-related libraries.[9][10]
Denis ran multiple system checks, looking for processor and register characteristics, to evade emulation and analysis.[11]
Dyre can detect sandbox analysis environments by inspecting the process list and Registry.[12][13]
EvilBunny's dropper has checked the number of processes and the length and strings of its own file name to identify if the malware is in a sandbox environment.[14]
Evilnum has used a component called TerraLoader to check certain hardware and file information to detect sandboxed environments. [15]
Ferocious can run anti-sandbox checks using the Microsoft Excel 4.0 function GET.WORKSPACE to determine the OS version, if there is a mouse present, and if the host is capable of playing sounds.[16]
FinFisher obtains the hardware device list and checks if the MD5 of the vendor ID is equal to a predefined list in order to check for sandbox/virtualized environments.[17]
Frankenstein has used WMI queries to check if various security applications were running, including VMWare and Virtualbox.[18]
GoldMax will check if it is being run in a virtualized environment by comparing the collected MAC address to c8:27:cc:c2:37:5a.[19][20]
Grandoreiro can detect VMWare via its I/O port and Virtual PC via the vpcext instruction.[21]

GravityRAT uses WMI to check the BIOS and manufacturer information for strings like "VMWare", "Virtual", and "XEN" and another WMI request to get the current temperature of the hardware to determine if it's a virtual machine environment. [22]
GuLoader has the ability to perform anti-VM and anti-sandbox checks using string hashing, the API call EnumWindows, and checking for Qemu guest agent.[23]
InvisiMole can check for artifacts of VirtualBox, Virtual PC and VMware environment, and terminate itself if they are detected.[24]
Lazarus Group has used tools to detect sandbox or VMware services through identifying the presence of a debugger or related services.[25]

Lucifer can check for specific usernames, computer names, device drivers, DLL's, and virtual devices associated with sandboxed environments and can enter an infinite loop and stop itself if any are detected.[26]
MegaCortex has checked the number of CPUs in the system to avoid being run in a sandbox or emulator.[27]
NativeZone has checked if Vmware or VirtualBox VM is running on a compromised host.[28]
ObliqueRAT can halt execution if it identifies processes belonging to virtual machine software or analysis tools.[29]
OilRig has used macros to verify if a mouse is connected to a compromised machine.[30]
Okrum's loader can check the amount of physical memory and terminates itself if the host has less than 1.5 Gigabytes of physical memory in total.[31]

OopsIE performs several anti-VM and sandbox checks on the victim's machine. One technique the group has used was to perform a WMI query SELECT * FROM MSAcpi_ThermalZoneTemperature to check the temperature to see if itâ€™s running in a virtual environment.[3]
OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D has variants that check a number of system parameters to see if it is being run on real hardware or in a virtual machine environment, such as sysctl hw.model.[32][33]
P8RAT can check the compromised host for processes associated with VMware or VirtualBox environments.[34]
PlugX checks if VMware tools is running in the background by searching for any process named "vmtoolsd".[35]

Pupy has a module that checks a number of indicators on the system to determine if its running on a virtual machine.[37]
QakBot can check the compromised host for the presence of multiple executables associated with analysis tools and halt execution if any are found.[38][39]
Remcos searches for Sandboxie and VMware on the system.[40]
RogueRobin uses WMI to check BIOS version for VBOX, bochs, qemu, virtualbox, and vm to check for evidence that the script might be executing within an analysis environment. [41][42]
ROKRAT can check for VMware-related files and DLLs related to sandboxes.[43][44][45]
Smoke Loader scans processes to perform anti-VM checks. [46]
SodaMaster can check for the presence of the Registry key HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Applications\VMwareHostOpen.exe before proceeding to its main functionality.[34]
SUNBURST checked the domain name of the compromised host to verify it was running in a real environment.[47]
SynAck checks its directory location in an attempt to avoid launching in a sandbox.[48][49]

UBoatRAT checks for virtualization software such as VMWare, VirtualBox, or QEmu on the compromised machine.[51]
WastedLocker checked if UCOMIEnumConnections and IActiveScriptParseProcedure32 Registry keys were detected as part of its anti-analysis technique.[52]
yty has some basic anti-sandbox detection that tries to detect Virtual PC, Sandboxie, and VMware. [53]

FELIXROOT encrypts collected data with AES and Base64 and then sends it to the C2 server.[21]
Following data collection, FIN6 has compressed log files into a ZIP archive prior to staging and exfiltration.[22]
Gold Dragon encrypts data using Base64 before being sent to the command and control server.[23]
Honeybee adds collected files to a temp.zip file saved in the %temp% folder, then base64 encodes it and uploads it to control server.[24]
The Ke3chang group has been known to compress data before exfiltration.[25]
Kessel can RC4-encrypt credentials before sending to the C2.[26]
KONNI has encrypted data and files prior to exfiltration.[27]
Lazarus Group has compressed exfiltrated data with RAR and used RomeoDelta malware to archive specified directories in .zip format, encrypt the .zip file, and upload it to C2. [28][29][30][31]
Leviathan has archived victim's data prior to exfiltration.[32]
LightNeuron contains a function to encrypt and store emails that it collects.[33]
Lizar has encrypted data before sending it to the server.[34]
Lurid can compress data before sending it.[35]
Machete stores zipped files with profile data from installed web browsers.[36]
menuPass has encrypted files and information before exfiltration.[37][38]
NETWIRE has the ability to compress archived screenshots.[39]
Patchwork encrypted the collected files' path with AES and then encoded them with base64.[40]
Pillowmint has encrypted stolen credit card information with AES and further encoded it with Base64.[41]
After collecting documents from removable media, Prikormka compresses the collected files, and encrypts it with Blowfish.[42]
Proton zips up files before exfiltrating them.[43]
Remexi encrypts and adds all gathered browser data into files for upload to C2.[44]
RunningRAT contains code to compress files.[23]
ShimRatReporter used LZ compression to compress initial reconnaissance reports before sending to the C2.[45]
TAINTEDSCRIBE has used FileReadZipSend to compress a file and send to C2.[46]
VERMIN encrypts the collected files using 3-DES.[47]
WellMail can archive files on the compromised host.[48]
XCSSET will compress entire ~/Desktop folders excluding all .git folders, but only if the total data size is under 200MB.[49]
Zebrocy has used a method similar to RC4 as well as AES for encryption and hexadecimal for encoding data before exfiltration. [50][51][52]

Flame has a module named BeetleJuice that contains Bluetooth functionality that may be used in different ways, including transmitting encoded information from the infected system over the Bluetooth protocol, acting as a Bluetooth beacon, and identifying other Bluetooth devices in the vicinity.[1]
Attor has a file uploader plugin that automatically exfiltrates the collected data and log files to the C2 server.[1]
CosmicDuke exfiltrates collected files automatically over FTP to remote servers.[2]
Crutch has automatically exfiltrated stolen files to Dropbox.[3]
Doki has used a script that gathers information from a hardcoded list of IP addresses and uploads to an Ngrok URL.[4]
Ebury can automatically exfiltrate gathered SSH credentials.[5]
Frankenstein has collected information via Empire, which is automatically sent the data back to the adversary's C2.[6]
Gamaredon Group has used modules that automatically upload gathered documents to the C2 server.[7]
Honeybee performs data exfiltration is accomplished through the following command-line command: from (- --).txt.[8]
Ke3chang has performed frequent and scheduled data exfiltration from compromised networks.[9]
LightNeuron can be configured to automatically exfiltrate files under a specified directory.[10]
Macheteâ€™s collected files are exfiltrated automatically to remote servers.[11]
Peppy has the ability to automatically exfiltrate files and keylogs.[12]

Rover automatically searches for files on local drives based on a predefined list of file extensions and sends them to the command and control server every 60 minutes. Rover also automatically sends keylogger files and screenshots to the C2 server on a regular timeframe.[13]

USBStealer automatically exfiltrates collected files via removable media when an infected device connects to an air-gapped victim machine after initially being connected to an internet-enabled victim machine. [21]

jRAT can be configured to reconnect at certain intervals.[8]

Machete sends stolen data to the C2 server every 10 minutes.[12]

POSHSPY uploads data in 2048-byte chunks.[10]

Threat Group-3390 actors have split RAR files for exfiltration into parts.[12]

ftp may be used to exfiltrate data separate from the main command and control protocol.[17][18]

APT28 added "junk data" to each encoded string, preventing trivial decoding without knowledge of the junk removal algorithm. Each implant was given a "junk length" value when created, tracked by the controller software to allow seamless communication but prevent analysis of the command protocol on the wire.[1]
BendyBear has used byte randomization to obscure its behavior.[2]
Downdelph inserts pseudo-random characters between each original character during encoding of C2 network requests, making it difficult to write signatures on them.[3]
GoldMax has used decoy traffic to surround its malicious network traffic to avoid detection.[4]
GrimAgent can pad C2 messages with random generated values.[5]
P2P ZeuS added junk data to outgoing UDP packets to peer implants.[6]
P8RAT can send randomly-generated data as part of its C2 communication.[7]
PLEAD samples were found to be highly obfuscated with junk code.[8][9]
SUNBURST added junk bytes to its C2 over HTTP.[10]
TrailBlazer has used random identifier strings to obscure its C2 operations and result codes.[11]
Turian can insert pseudo-random characters into its network encryption setup.[12]
WellMess can use junk data in the Base64 string for additional obfuscation.[13]
APT29 has used steganography to hide C2 communications in images.[1]
Axiom has used steganography to hide its C2 communications.[2]
Daserf can use steganography to hide malicious code downloaded to the victim.[3]
When the Duqu command and control is operating over HTTP or HTTPS, Duqu uploads data to its controller by appending it to a blank JPG file.[4]
HAMMERTOSS is controlled via commands that are appended to image files.[5]
LightNeuron is controlled via commands that are embedded into PDFs and JPGs using steganographic methods.[6]
RDAT can process steganographic images attached to email messages to send and receive C2 commands. RDAT can also embed additional messages within BMP images to communicate with the RDAT operator.[7]
Sliver can encode binary data into a .PNG file for C2 communication.[8]
SUNBURST C2 data attempted to appear as benign XML related to .NET assemblies or as a faux JSON blob.[9][10][11]
ZeroT has retrieved stage 2 payloads as Bitmap images that use Least Significant Bit (LSB) steganography.[12][13]
Zox has used the .PNG file format for C2 communications.[2]
BADCALL uses a FakeTLS method during C2.[1]
Bankshot generates a false TLS handshake using a public certificate to disguise C2 network communications.[2]
Cobalt Strike can mimic the HTTP protocol for C2 communication, while hiding the actual data in either an HTTP header, URI parameter, the transaction body, or appending it to the URI.[3]

FakeM C2 traffic attempts to evade detection by resembling data generated by legitimate messenger applications, such as MSN and Yahoo! messengers. Additionally, some variants of FakeM use modified SSL code for communications back to C2 servers, making SSL decryption ineffective.[4]
FALLCHILL uses fake Transport Layer Security (TLS) to communicate with its C2 server.[5]
HARDRAIN uses FakeTLS to communicate with its C2 server.[6]
Higaisa used a FakeTLS session for C2 communications.[7]
InvisiMole can mimic HTTP protocol with custom HTTP "verbs" HIDE, ZVVP, and NOP.[8][9]
KeyBoy uses custom SSL libraries to impersonate SSL in C2 traffic.[10]

Lazarus Group malware also uses a unique form of communication encryption known as FakeTLS that mimics TLS but uses a different encryption method, potentially evading SSL traffic inspection/decryption.[11][12][13][14]
Okrum mimics HTTP protocol for C2 communication, while hiding the actual messages in the Cookie and Set-Cookie headers of the HTTP requests.[15]
SUNBURST masqueraded its network traffic as the Orion Improvement Program (OIP) protocol.[16]
TAINTEDSCRIBE has used FakeTLS for session authentication.[17]
FlawedAmmyy may obfuscate portions of the initial C2 handshake.[1]
Operation Wocao has encrypted IP addresses used for "Agent" proxy hops with RC4.[2]
RDAT has used encoded data within subdomains as AES ciphertext to communicate from the host to the C2.[3]
SideTwist can embed C2 responses in the source code of a fake Flickr webpage.[4]
SLOTHFULMEDIA has hashed a string containing system information prior to exfiltration via POST requests.[5]
TrailBlazer can masquerade its C2 traffic as legitimate Google Notifications HTTP requests.[6]
Anchor can use secondary C2 servers for communication after establishing connectivity and relaying victim information to primary C2 servers.[1]
AppleSeed can use a second channel for C2 when the primary channel is in upload mode.[2]
APT41 used the Steam community page as a fallback mechanism for C2.[3]
Bazar has the ability to use an alternative C2 server if the primary server fails.[4]
BISCUIT malware contains a secondary fallback command and control server that is contacted after the primary command and control server.[5][6]
BlackEnergy has the capability to communicate over a backup channel via plus.google.com.[7]
Cardinal RAT can communicate over multiple C2 host and port combinations.[8]
CharmPower can change its C2 channel once every 360 loops by retrieving a new domain from the actorsâ€?S3 bucket.[9]
CHOPSTICK can switch to a new C2 channel if the current one is broken.[10]
Crutch has used a hardcoded GitHub repository as a fallback channel.[11]
Derusbi uses a backup communication method with an HTTP beacon.[12]
DustySky has two hard-coded domains for C2 servers; if the first does not respond, it will try the second.[13]
Ebury has implemented a fallback mechanism to begin using a DGA when the attacker hasn't connected to the infected system for three days.[14]
Exaramel for Linux can attempt to find a new C2 server if it receives an error.[15]
FatDuke has used several C2 servers per targeted organization.[16]
FIN7's Harpy backdoor malware can use DNS as a backup channel for C2 if HTTP fails.[17]
Gelsemium can use multiple domains and protocols in C2.[18]
HOPLIGHT has multiple C2 channels in place in case one fails.[19]
InvisiMole has been configured with several servers available for alternate C2 communications.[20][21]

JHUHUGIT tests if it can reach its C2 server by first attempting a direct connection, and if it fails, obtaining proxy settings and sending the connection through a proxy, and finally injecting code into a running browser if the proxy method fails.[22]
Kazuar can accept multiple URLs for C2 servers.[23]
Kwampirs uses a large list of C2 servers that it cycles through until a successful connection is established.[24]
Lazarus Group malware SierraAlfa sends data to one of the hard-coded C2 servers chosen at random, and if the transmission fails, chooses a new C2 server to attempt the transmission again.[25][26]
Linfo creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can change C2 servers.[27]
Machete has sent data over HTTP if FTP failed, and has also used a fallback server.[28]
MiniDuke uses Google Search to identify C2 servers if its primary C2 method via Twitter is not working.[29]

Mis-Type first attempts to use a Base64-encoded network protocol over a raw TCP socket for C2, and if that method fails, falls back to a secondary HTTP-based protocol to communicate to an alternate C2 server.[30]
Mythic can use a list of C2 URLs as fallback mechanisms in case one IP or domain gets blocked.[31]
NETEAGLE will attempt to detect if the infected host is configured to a proxy. If so, NETEAGLE will send beacons via an HTTP POST request; otherwise it will send beacons via UDP/6000.[32]
OilRig malware ISMAgent falls back to its DNS tunneling mechanism if it is unable to reach the C2 server over HTTP.[33]
PipeMon can switch to an alternate C2 domain when a particular date has been reached.[34]
QUADAGENT uses multiple protocols (HTTPS, HTTP, DNS) for its C2 server as fallback channels if communication with one is unsuccessful.[35]
RainyDay has the ability to switch between TCP and HTTP for C2 if one method is not working.[36]
RDAT has used HTTP if DNS C2 communications were not functioning.[37]
S-Type primarily uses port 80 for C2, but falls back to ports 443 or 8080 if initial communication fails.[30]
ShimRat has used a secondary C2 location if the first was unavailable.[38]

POSHSPY uses a DGA to derive command and control URLs from a word list.[6]
